rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Dempsey is honestly one of the best professors I've had. She really cares about her students and holds review sessions before each exam to make sure students understand the material. She gives students so many opportunities to learn the material. She made chemistry at 8AM bearable for me and she's a great lecturer.
This class was one of the best I have had at unc so far! She is a great lecturer, very specific and clear. You know what is expected of you as long as you are willing to put in the work.

Professor Dempsey gives some of the best lectures I have had at UNC. She is extremely clear on what content to go over and never demands more than you can handle. Her tests can be difficult at first, but the flipped classroom really teaches you the material so that by the final, you barely have to review the old stuff. Would definitely take again.
She's really nice and a good professor. Explains concepts clearly, I guess. I had a heavy load, so I'm sure if I would've put more effort into the class, I could've gotten an A- at least.

Gives you a lot of readingHW but breaks it down for you in class. Tests are not as hard as textbook practice problems and not too bad in general (final seems to be a bit harder than the midterms). Review sessions and her own Q&As are great. She will put a small curve (4-5 points) on midterms if need be. If you work hard you can get an A.

Professor Dempsey is awesome. So far, she's my favorite teacher here at UNC. Her lectures are extremely straightforward, and she tells you everything you need to know to succeed in her class. If one of your semester exams is lower than the final, she drops it. There are also really big review sessions before every exam. Study notes from review.

Dempsey is great. Her lectures are very clear, interactive, and interesting. Even at 8 am I never had trouble paying attention. She tells you exactly what to study and explains everything very clearly, going over multitudes of relevant practice problems. Attend her Q and A and review sessions, and do the book problems at the end.

I always feel like the science teachers at UNC are just out to fail you. However, Professor Dempsey went way out of her way to help us and make sure we succeeded. I went to her office hours once and she was a very genuine, caring woman. As mentioned, the three hour review sessions were vital! But.. I made an 89.6 and she didn't round. So that sucks

Professor Dempsey is very sweet and is very passionate about Chemistry and her students. She's very helpful and offers extra credit opportunities. Unfortunately, Chemistry is just hard. She had 3 hour review sessions for every exam including the final. She really wants her students to pass. She curves sometimes as well.

Chem 101 is definitely one of the most daunting classes at UNC but Dempsey made it as least miserable as possible.  She is entertaining and a good lecturer.  Her tests are relatively hard, but what chem tests aren't.  From what I've heard of other professors, she's the best to have for 101.

I would not recommend taking this class. Professor Dempsey is very intelligent but she is not a good professor. She does not know how to pace herself during class and ends up rushing through chapters that have significant content on the exams. She is very nice and has a passion for chemistry but is not a good professor.

She is extremely helpful and fair, especially around exam times. I always knew exactly what was going to be on her exams and what to study. Her extra assignments are easy for the most part! I have really enjoyed chemistry with Dempsey and would recommend her for any chemistry course.

Maybe the best professor I've had so far in my (albeit short) time at UNC.  Yes, the class is moderately hard, but she's one of these professors that actively finds extra time to help students, maybe more so than any of the other 101 professors this year.  I don't know if she'll be teaching 101 or 102 in the Fall, but if she does, take her section.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Miller is extremely passionate about inorganic chemistry and I enjoyed his class. Taking his class without having taken organic proved to be a little more difficult than I imagined, but it was very manageable. His finally is really tough but the other tests are pretty straightforward. ATTEND recitation; very helpful. Adjusted graded scale.

Dr. Miller is clearly very very smart, and doesn't always realize how difficult the material can be. People had told me this would be the easiest chemistry class I would take, but that is definitely not the case. Be prepared to study a lot! He does provide a lot of review material, so definitely use that to review for tests.

Great teacher that is willing to help whenever you need it. Tests are not too difficult as long as you know the material he teaches. Textbook helps for understanding certain topics but study the notes. Overall not a tough class, you just have to be able to think about inorganic chemistry. Grading scale is adjusted. Agree w/ bottom reivew (5/8/15)

Dr. Miller is a very tough professor. The information in Chem251 is not really all that hard- only a few new topics from gen chem, but mostly  just "gen chem on steroids." That being said, his tests are quite difficult and designed to trick you. He doesn't curve, but does change the grading scale (90-100 A, 87-89  A-). The final was very hard.

CHEM 251 is a two credit hour course. He structured the course so there are two lectures each week with an optional problem session (usually Fridays). The grade was mostly based on homework and test grades. There were a couple extra credit options.

Dr. Miller is extremely nice for how smart he is.  He explains concepts well, although the teaching pace is fast and the book wasn't as detailed as his lectures.  He definitely cares if his students are learning but his tests are challenging. The practice problems in the book do not reflect his exams and that's mainly the only extra practice...

He was a great teacher who was very interested in having students succeed and getting them interested in research. That being said he is not an easy teacher. He will challenge you, I recommend taking 261 (Organic Chemistry I) before taking him. It will make the class a lot easier.
Did not enjoy the class or his style of teaching.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: She is researcher and not a professor. Though she is at a disadvantage because the class is only scheduled for two days a week, she rushes through material and does not prepare you for any exam. The majority of you preparation will come on your own or with a partner. She does not speak to the level of students who have never taken this class.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Prof. Glish is a good professor, but CHEM 241H was pretty tough with him. Although we had a "curve" for each individual exam, it wasn't much really of a help to our grade compared to the regular CHEM 241. I would highly suggest taking regular CHEM 241 if you can.
Prof Glish is a really awesome guy. Very approachable and nice sense of humor. His tests are straightforward--do the book problems. Generous curve as well. Recommend!

Never heard of Glish prior to taking his Chem 241 class, but he quickly turned into my favorite teacher at UNC.  Must do all readings and work tons of problems.  Very approachable if you have any questions and is fair about point-spreads and test curves.  Tests will challenge you and you review old material for the final. Got a B. Recommend.

If he taught just a little bit, he'd make this class less painful. During lectures, he basically goes over the content of his power point slides... I don't think, he realizes how much hatred he induces in us towards the course.

I had Glish back in the day.  He looked at my grades and said there were no way I could get an A.  Luckily, if we scored an A on the final we got an A (I got an A).  His teaching was not that great and the book was more clear than him.
Absolutely terrible.  Avoid if you can.

Posts lectures online, but should attend class for bonus points, class is boring but not unbearable.  DO HOMEWORK PROBLEMS, although they are lengthy and not easy, you will learn the material and the problems frequently appear on the exams with slightly different numbers or wording so its worth it.
No Comments

This class was ok.  Lecture was pretty much just power points posted on blackboard beforehand.  To keep students involved in lecture he would have multiple choice with remotes to respond in order to earn extra credit.  Test were on the harder side, be sure to study old tests!
His tests are very tricky!

Can not keep his politics and teaching separate. Validates opinions by saying he has an economics degree. Has in class questions and jeopardy for extra credit. Teaches quickly, lectures do not prepare you for tests. Must teach yourself. Optional homework.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: 3 midterms. Final is cumulative. You can replace your midterm grades if you do better on that section of the final. But that's not going to happen. Do well and study hard for midterms, because you'll do bad on the ridiculous final. No point of going to class, no attendance grade, no homework, just tests. Sucks. Hard. He doesn't teach well at all.

As far as chem classes go this one was great. Jorgenson writes everything he's talking about on the board, which means its easy to follow and you have plenty of time to take notes. The tests are all multiple choice and they are almost identical to the practice exams. He also lets you replace exam grades with sections of the final which is nice.

Jorgenson has been my favorite professor so far at UNC. Cutest and funniest old man ever. I want to adopt him as my grandpa. Go to class and take good notes, do practice problems and practice exams - you'll be good to go. I even went to a couple of his office hours (basically Q&A sessions) and it helped a ton! Definitely recommend!

He is the cutest old man and is very famous in analytical chemistry. Easiest chem class I have taken. Tests are very similar to his practice exams. Sometimes he just changes the numbers. His lectures are boring and he is a little hard to hear & the textbook is useless (but do the problems he assigns). You can redeem yourself on the final!!

This class was a bore. Poor Jorgenson because he is a really nice man, but the class was so boring that I never went. The final was extremely hard. There isn't much more to say. Chem 241 was one of the worst classes I took here. The only good thong is that he will replace your exam grades with how well you did on final, except the final blows.

He is a great lecturer and goes by a very traditional chalkboard teach method. I would recommend going to his office hours and really studying the practice tests. Even though he is really successful and distinguished in his field, Dr. Jorgenson is so humble and approachable. He will not be teaching for much longer so take his class whe you can!
Great professor. Study your notes and do the practice exams and the assigned problems and you will be fine. I love him, he is adorable and known a lot. I admire him :)

Dr. Jorgenson was great!  I don't know what's up with these other comments, but he was clear, funny, and knew the material well!  Tests were fair, if you went to lecture and did the practice problems, it wasn't too hard to get an A on his exams.  That said, like any chemistry class, going to lecture and doing the homework is easier said than done.

Professor Jorgenson is an AMAZING professor!  He was hilarious!  He did multiple choice tests.  This was my favorite class!  He told stories during his lectures to keep you engaged and they helped you remember the stuff.  I LOVED THIS CLASS!  He is a great man and a great professor.  Not only is he a genius, he invented cappillary electrophoresis!

Professor Jorgenson is very intelligent and knows the subject matter, but that is the only positive thing to say about him.  His teaching skills are lacking. It's great that he understands the material, but he is an ineffective educator.  If you take his class, be prepared to teach yourself and get a good tutor.

Worst professor I've ever had at UNC...or anywhere for that matter.  He is a complete waste of time and energy and a useless human being.  He invented capillary electrophoresis, but the sad thing is HE CANNOT TEACH!  If you can teach yourself, good luck. Otherwise, STAY AWAY FROM HIM and get a prof who knows what he/she is doing!

Nice man, terrible professor.  He is obviously brilliant, but cannot convey the information very well to students.  He is hard to follow, moves way too quickly, and his lectures were nothing like his tests.  I taught myself everything I learned in this class from the book.  AVOID HIM AT ALL COSTS
dificult course but very good prof

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I love Prof. Lockett. I hate chemistry most of the time (which sucks when you're premed) and he made every single class enjoyable. I had him for a summer session, which is difficult enough for 241, and he did what he could to help our grades and ensure our success. He's super nice, gives great examples in class, and is just a great professor.

I had Professor Lockett for Analytical during summer school, and he was amazing! He's someone who, above all, cares that students understand the big concepts in the class. Rather than having to provide a steep curve, he gives poll everywhere problems in class for extra credit. Lockett is a very calm and kind person--a true legend!

Lockett is enjoyed by a lot of students and understandably so. He's a very funny professor who does his best to make sure students understand analytical chemistry. The only problem is, he doesn't seem to know how to do math. He makes at least daily math errors in solving problems in a class where math is essential. It's shocking.
A great seminar for science major transfer students. Which helps you to know some faculties in the departments and teach you skills to find an undergraduate research.

simply put, this guy is a legend. He truly cares about if you understand the material.  gives extra credit because he wants people to learn and not feel down in a very difficult class.  Do everything you can to take his class.

I'm a big fan of Professor Lockett because he cares for his students (inside and outside of academics), and it really shows. Exams are hard, but really what would you expect from analytical chemistry? He definitely wants to challenge you, but in a passionate, pedantic, and ego-free way. Highly recommend him!

Dr. Lockett is honestly one of the best chemistry professors at UNC. He really wants each and every one of his students to be successful. He gives out a ton of extra credit points that'll help buffer your grade. His tests may be challenging, but if you work hard and do the practice problems (of which there are many), you'll be fine. He's also funny

Dr. Lockett is the best Chem professor I've taken at UNC. He is fair, really funny, and more than willing to help. You get extra credit for poll everywhere and it makes a huge difference in your final grade. I highly suggest going to his office hours when you can. It's a tough class, but if you put the work in you'll be ok!

Dr. Lockett is the most fair professor I've had at UNC. He genuinely wants his students to do well and gives them ample opportunities to do so. His tests are all fair and he curves the exams. I highly recommend going to lectures because he grants extra credit for poll everywhere. I had 35 extra points at the end of the semester because of this.

Professor Lockett was one of the most fair professors I have ever had at Carolina. Yes, his tests were difficult, but they were definitely doable if you studied. He is also BIG on poll-everywhere, awarding as much as 40 extra credit points, so be sure to attend lecture. Overall a great class.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: just went through powerpoints, not interesting and messes up through class...class is very boring, fell asleep through the few classes that I went to, sucks as a teacher

Tests are copy of practice tests, so class is rediculously easy, her class despite how sweet/ energetic is not worth going to, she confuses everyone and mis-speaks often making it hard to follow when you already know the material.

Nice person out of class, VERY confusing, makes you say HuH? Doesnt clearly answer questions, and is very sporatic. Class is based off powerpoints, but if you study all material and practice tests you should do fine (at least i did on my first test) Does involve reading from text and the more practice problems you do, the better off you are.  Overall not bad, you have to learn on your own, but she's alright.
No Comments
No Comments
horrible! no calculator! bad explainations, just not helpful at all. unless you're a bright chem person and understand chem then you'll be okay.
not meant to be a teacher

Unclear answers to questions, doesn't know how to explain material even though she's smart... office hours don't help... reads out powerpoint slides in class which she publishes anyway.. powerpoints aren't very helpful.. on last test: class average was 59
No Comments
Very scattered teaching style, rarely coherently answers questions. Skips around through the book and is a VERY tough grader, especially with sig figs.

Teaches through powerpoints and skips a lot of information in the book, which she tests you on later. 3 Tests and a final. Uses webassign and doesn't allow calculators. Teaches fast and rarely stops to answer questions.
Hard prof for Chem.  I see she teaches some 100+ levels and you can tell.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: a very good lecture. excellent ability to answer the questions in class and very honest. Introducing new knowledge and progress for old text and keep correcting the statement, results ..
Wonderful course!!!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. You's Chem 421 course is very difficult as an undergrad. You can take it before 420, but I would only suggest doing so if you're extremely comfortable with your proficiency in organic chemistry. On the plus side it makes Chem 420 seem more like a review.

He's funny and a good teacher if you go to his office hours, read the book, and do the homework, etc... It's difficult to do well in any class if you don't prepare well, especially orgo2. This is the same, sometimes he's difficult to understand in lecture because English isn't his first language, but one-on-one he's much more clear for some reason.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Cannot imagine taking Chem 261 or 262 without Crimmins, undoubtedly the best for this class.  Go to office hours, as he is extremely understanding and helpful.  Many of these professors push off extra teaching/help to TA's, but he cares about his students for review sessions. Rough class but no tests have curveballs, just need lots of time to study

I got an A in 261 with Crimmins and now an A in 262 with him again. By far the best organic chemistry professor at UNC. However, don't let you think that this is a walk in the park - you still have to do your part to get the grade you want. 262 in my opinion was harder than 262, and the average in the class was also lower than 261. Mike is awesome!

Dr. Crimmins is by far the best science professor I've had here because he is FAIR and doesn't try to trick you like so many others. At the same time though, fair definitely doesn't mean easy, but there's nothing easy about Organic chemistry anyways. Take him! You'll regret it if you don't because he's such an awesome guy.

Crimmins is one of the best professors I have had thus far. He genuinely wants all his students to do well and will do whatever he can to get you your best grade at the end of the semester. Go to his office hours; he dedicates so much of his time outside of class to helping students! He is the best organic professor.
One of the best professors I've ever had.  He teaches the material extremely well.  Just watch the videos, show up to class, and work the practice tests religiously and you will do well.
Best professor ever - I love Mike Crimmins. Tests are very straightforward and fair, but partial credit is minimal to non-existent so you need to know your stuff.

Dr. Crimmins is a phenomenal teacher. He is really engaging in class and gives students lots of outside resources like videos and practice problems. He gives his students all the things they need to be successful, but they have to study and work too. That's just the reality with Orgo. Definitely one of the best teachers I've had at UNC.
Has an online library of videos explaining the topics in his class. He or his class mentors are often available for help.

He is super easy to talk to and he respects his students. It is easy to get one on one help with either Crimmins or the TAs. He posts lots of helpful resources on the course site. Tests are hard, but they are fairly written. Best professor I've had at UNC hands down.

He's a really nice guy. Don't be afraid to ask questions in class. There's textbook readings and videos to watch. There's a clicker quiz every day, and you get to talk to your neighbors about questions, which is always nice. He gives practice tests, which are helpful. The content is pretty hard and requires good 3D-visualization skills.

If you have the opportunity to take organic chemistry (1, 2 ,or both) with Dr. Crimmins, do it. Definitely the best chemistry professor I have had at UNC. He is great at explaining concepts, knows how to write fair exams, and is truly a good guy.

Honestly the BEST professor I have ever had at UNC. His expectations for class are very clear and if you trust him and does what he says you WILL succeed. Tests are very fair and similar to practice exams. Offers plenty of extra help sessions. The workload is very reasonable for Orgo 1. To top it all off he is genuinely nice person who really cares

I'm not sure what changed between 2007 and when he came back to teaching in 2014, but I don't even recognize the person the other comments are describing. His lectures are very clear and concise. You can tell he puts a lot of time into organizing material into a way that will make the most sense. He has weekly Q&A sessions and last minute reviews.

Professor Crimmins was an extremely passionate teacher. He actually cares about students understanding chemistry, and it shows in how much effort he puts into making his lectures clear. His outlines are a little harder to follow but they really aren't necessary if you pay attention and read the book beforehand. Use the book! It helped a lot

He is very engaging and seems invested in students learning the material. The material by default is relatively difficult but his lectures are organized to teach you efficiently and he offers weekly review sessions. Tests can be hard, but its very similar to the problems in the text book. He's definitely the best chem professor I've had here.
He is friendly and his lectures are clear. His online videos are pretty helpful. He offers Q&A sessions every week.

Seriously, how does Prof. Crimmins have bad reviews?? He's an awesome lecturer, great at explaining the material, always willing to help during office hours, and he's funny. I guess I can see how others might find him condescending, but it's just because he wants you to do well. Take Crimmins. He rocks.

I agree-Crimmins is a condescending jerk-he doesn't seem to have much use for pre-med students or people who won't kiss his butt. He is definitely one of those professors who is more interested in his research than teaching. He doesn't make time to help those for whom orgo doesn't come naturally. Can't imagine being a grad student in that lab.

I found Crimmins to be engaging, but he was often condescending towards the class. He has very high expectations and knows his class is hard... probably prides himself on it. Good jokes, though. Not horrible, but not fantastic either.

Nice guy.  The lectures were excellent, he had the whole class laughing on multiple occasions.  Of course, it is OChem II, so it is quite difficult.  If you like multiple choice final exams, you might like this class.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: In CHEM733, Dr. Thompson led discussions of journal articles describing different types of fluorescence microscopy.  She was very enthusiastic, as she herself had pioneered fluorescence techniques.  She was very patient, explained the technical aspects of microscopy with great clarity &  taught us to read scientific literature with a critical eye.
Very boring lecturer, doesn't know what she is talking about sometimes.  If you read the book and do the mastering you will pass without going to a single lecture.  Powerpoints are all posted online

You don't learn anything in this class. She rambles on abut things that don't pertain to what you need to learn and her tests are extra hard for no reason. She even said she made the test too long for the time we are given and still made us take the test. I would not take her as a professor at all. Avoid at all costs

This is literally the worst teacher I've had at Carolina. I did well in the class, but I worked harder in this class than I did in Math 383- Differential Equations. You basically have to teach yourself everything. She is not clear and you can tell that she doesn't care. Avoid her like the plague.

Worst professor possible.  You don't receive formula sheets, she doesn't provide practice tests, and she acts dismissive in office hours.  ANYONE would be better than Thompson.  Tests are 10+ pages with the final exam over 20 pages long.  The kicker is that she's tough and you don't learn anything since she reads off of the powerpoint.

Terrible professor. She provides no practice tests or even study guides for her exams. She does the bare minimum for the course. Her lectures are dull and monotone and she never clearly articulates what you should know. Would definitely not recommend her unless you enjoy learning everything on your own.

I would avoid taking this class. The lectures do not help at all, but luckily attendance is not required. Her lectures are monotone and confusing. They also have unnecessary mathematical and biological information on them. You basically have to teach yourself with the book problems.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: AVOID. Not clear at all, did not come out of the class at al prepared for Chem 102. Wish I had known going in to wait to take it with a different professor.
He is confusing and a poor lecturer. Have to teach yourself from the textbook basically. His lectures are unorganized and his handwriting is poor. Take this class with a different professor.

Pielak is not a good lecturer and is often sometimes confusing. There are only three tests plus a final test. None of them are a walk in the park, but they aren't horribly difficult. You definitely need to study.

DO NOT TAKE PIELAK IF HES YOUR FIRST CHEM PROFESSOR!!!! It is very discouraging taking his class if you want to go into the sciences. His teaching style is all over the place and he doesn't do helpful examples, which can be hard to dive into for incoming first year students. He is also condescending at office hours.

The lectures will keep you awake but not very helpful. I recommend studying the textbook because he frequently rip questions straight from there, such as example problems of oxidation. Tests are fairly hard. And Pielak is mean at office hours. Wouldn't move my friend's exam date though he had to compete for UNC in mountain biking.

Very confusing lectures, no chance for practice problems in class, makes tests very difficult. I took AP chem and got a 3 on the exam so I took this class again for clarity, but I came out of it just as confused or maybe even a little more confused than when I signed up. Make sure you find a way to practice problems on your own.
I would never recommend taking chem 101 with him, nice guy, but no. Seriously.
I thought Pielak was a wonderful professor.  You will do well in the class if you are willing to put in the work.  He is always willing to help and even gives practice tests before each exam

The lectures weren't too bad, but he glazed over difficult topics.  The homework is not assigned, but you should do it.  I only learned and passed by reading the textbook and doing the homework.  I probably could have skipped class, read all the chapters,  and still received the same grade.

Dr. Pielak is an amazing chemist I had never taken chemistry before and found it very difficult to do well on the tests. I got a 40 on the first test, and a 44 on the second test and before college I'd never gotten a C in my life! It took me devoting my life to this class to pass it. His bellcurve encourages competition within students

Unless you had a strong background in AP Chem, get a different professor.  He teaches like you should already know material, and tests are the only grades. Never does examples in class. He holds office hours at inconvenient times, and they are rarely helpful. If you can even get his attention to answer a question, he is arrogant and disrespectful.

Pielak is far too advanced to be teaching 101. His lectures were nothing like the tests and there are only 3 with a final. An A is virtually impossible unless you are already extremely knowledgeable of the content prior to taking the course. Avoid Pielak at all costs.

I dread having a professor like Dr. Pielak again. Excellent knowledge of chemistry, but he is not willing to share it with his 101 students. He has a bitter teaching style i.e. he occasionally reprimanded students on their questions. Although he gives decent notes, they don't help at all on exams. If he's your last resort, wait another semester.

Professor Pielak was by far the worst professorteacher I have ever had. As far as lectures go, they weren't terrible. He sometimes tells you exact questions that will be on the exam. However, everything else is essentially setting you up for failure. He gives no encouragement, and doesn't actually care how well his students do. Don't take him.

Pielak is too old for teaching Chemistry. He should stay with his research. Lectures were awful, unclear. There was no assignment or quiz. He had only four exams.  Pielak is not helpful. You need to teach yourself.

Pielak's not a horrible prof, but how class is structured is difficult. Only four grades-- the 3 hour exams & the final exam. The hour exams are optional, HW is also optional. This may sound good; you might be thinking, "YAY LESS WORK!".. WRONG. In order to survive class, you must READ AND SELF-TEACH a lot bc he does not go over a lot of examples.
Hardest class ever, I read and did the homework and am not passing this class at the moment... You have to go to the Chem resource center every day if you even want a chance.

If you are a scientist already, and have somehow dodged taking CHEM 101 at Chapel Hill so far,  take him. A majority of people who take Professor Pielak's Chemistry class are incoming first year students that are interested in pursuing science as a profession. These students are getting shafted by an obscenely advanced teacher for an intro class.

Please don't take this man. He gives some organic chemistry level questions on his 101 exams and expects people in his class to already be masters at chemistry. He is a smart man, but that makes him really condescending when you don't understand and not very good at teaching. He is not meant for a 101 course... or probably any others.

He isn't clear in lectures and gets off topic often. He offers practice tests which don't really relate to the actual tests. Average grades for the tests were between 60 and 70 and he doesn't curve so if you do poorly you're stuck with it. However, his tests are optional and if you take all three he drops the lowest grade. Office hours are useless.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Joe is the most awesome prof ever!!
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Wightman's lectures are boring, but he provides you with all of the information that will be tested on. He gives practice tests ahead of time, and the actual tests contain problems of equal difficulty. Attendance isn't required, and even though the class can be boring, it is beneficial to attend.

Dr. Wightman covers topics very clearly and at a reasonable pace. He works hard to keep his lectures organized. His tests are fair and he is helpful in office hours. However, his voice and lecture style can put some to sleep.
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Honestly one of the most interesting and engaging classes I've ever taken. He is naturally very funny and really has a talent for explaining difficult material in a simplified way. He is very upfront about his expectations, and if you're prepared to put in a solid week of hardcore studying before exams, you'll do fine. Made me love biochem!

I wouldn't know how Redinbo's lectures are, because I literally never went. Not once. Except to pick up my exams. And I got an A. All you have to do is memorize literally everything on the notes that he posts for each lecture. EVERYTHING. I made the mistake of underestimating that on the first exam and got in the 70s. 90+ on everything after that

Redinbo is a great professor and easy to listen to. Also, he takes the relevant material and puts it into clear, easy-to-read outlines and posts them.  They essentially tell you what will be on an exam. Exams are fair (all free response).  Class is mostly memorization. If you want to think more deeply about biochem, take an honors section.

One of the best professors I've learned from at UNC. If you're good at memorization, then expect an A. This guy is funny. He is great at simplifying things. This class is crossed-sect. with biol 430. This will be THE FIRST chemistry class I'll get an A in. As a biology major, these aren't easy to finest. Moreover, I actually enjoy lectures.
Super hot, funny, and overall easy teacher - take him for biochem for sure

He's a funny guy. Keeps you awake.  The material requires a lot of memorization of structures so do yourself a favor and start early - especially for the final.  The way he grades makes it much easier on students than it could be.  The averages were always high though - so don't even think about a curve.
he's a really funny lecturer, emphasizes the chemistry - be prepared to memorize and don't even bother buying the book you'll never use it

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: The honors classes can be intimidating, but Dr. Schoenfisch made it worth it. He's incredibly smart, but not intimidating, which is rare. Tests are the only grades, so be ready to study. He spends a few classes at the end of the year talking about his research, and that alone is worth the extra work of the honors class. He's the bomb

Go to class (which he cancels often). Its only a 2 unit course, so there's not much material compared to other chems. I took it with the lab and the work load wasn't bad. There are no assignments due, just tests. Due the suggested HW, similar to exams. No attendance taken, but go to class because not everything covered is in his power points.

If you have the chance to take his first year seminar, take it. He is a cool guy that likes to get to know his students on a personal level. He grades fairly and wants his students to succeed at UNC and in life.

Solid professor. Goes through the material rather quickly, but has Q/A sessions after class to clear things up. Tests were very fair. Questions came right from the practice problems most of the time. Overall, cool guy, willing to help. Took 241 over the summer (recommend), but be prepared for a load if also taking 241L at the same time.

Teaches extremely fast. 1/3 of classes are cancelled so material is crammed in. Material is sometimes boring but he throws in lots of jokes to mix it up. Grading policy is very fair, enables you to mess up. He's REALLY good if you ask questions outside of class, very nice guy and super helpful. He wants you to understand the material. Tests so-so.

He's really horrible at lecturing and if book-learning chemistry isn't your forte, stay away. However, his tests are fair and while he is condescending in class, he is much more receptive in office hours--I believe he wants to help us. Tests are very similar to the practice problems, so do those. The final is fair but challenging and comprehensive.

He is not clear in class, so you must rely on the textbook, which tends to be convoluted. His tests were somewhat fair if you did the homework, but the final will ruin your grade since he includes material on it that you never learned in class.
Cool guy, tests weren't hard at all.
Good professor! Very nice and helpful, and good at explaining concepts. Made class material that could be very painful fairly painless. Also seems passionate about his work!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Weeks really wants his students to do well. He gave guided notes for his lectures. There is required online homework (Aleks) but it will ultimately help you. If you do the work and attend class, the tests will be straightforward and easy. He gives motivational speeches so that's a plus.

He's a great professor and makes the chemistry easy to understand. Expect LOTS of ALEKS homework every week and you have to go to class for clicker questions. Tests are manageable for a chem weed-out class, but the final is worth 55% of your grade and is VERY difficult. Would recommend.

Seriously, if you don't have to take him--Do. Not. Take someone else's class. He is not good at answering questions and when he messes up he tries to shift the blame to whoever is asking him, calling them things like "particularly grumpy."

Dont even try to ask any questions to him. He just laughs you off and doesn't take you seriously. For instance, someone asked him to explain why water freezes on top rather than on the bottom and his answer was "water is really bizzare stuff don't over complicate it". Another asked if something would be on an exam and he answered "What do you think

Dr. Weeks seems a little stand-offish in class but he's a nice guy and he teaches the material really well. I definitely recommend going to office hours because he is much more open to questions involving course work, exams, or content during that time. Overall, was not a bad class

This is a very interesting Chemistry class because he tests you only on the quantitative portion of the material. If you are good at math then this class should be relatively easy. There is no homework grade, but non of the tests were exceptionally difficult. I would recommend this teacher over all the other 102 teachers.

There is a difference between being a good person and being a good professor. His class was very hard. Your grade is based off of three exams and the final- nothing else! If you do better on the final than on one of the exams, he'll drop that one and replace it with the final exam's. He makes his tests difficult. Pick another professor if you can.

Professor Weeks was a great teacher. He's really passionate about what he teaches and he makes it interesting. The tests are very similar to the h.w. problems, so if you do them, and read the chapters, the class is very do-able. You can get a solid B putting in about 70% effort. So, giving it your all can probably get you an A! :)

Professor Weeks is a good professor. He provides notes that you can print out and fill in in class and his tests are VERY similar to the practice problems done in class and the book problems he suggests doing.  Do the book problems and review the class problems and you should be fine.

Took quantitative analysis, 2nd semester gen chem.  Printable lecture notes which really helped out.  Walks through several problems in class.  Know your homework problems b/c test are very similar.  Average test scores in 60-ish range, curved grade by 2-3 points in the end but depends on class average.
Very hard, make sure you go to class and work the practice problems.......lucky for me he curved!
No Comments

I thought his lectures were clear and fairly interesting.  Sometimes he seems a bit curt or dismissive in answering questions, but I don't think he's trying to be mean.  He'll walk you through something, which some people find condescending.   Redo web assign and the bookwork until you have it mastered and the tests will be a breeze.
Not very helpful. takes off for not using his methods on test. mocks students when they ask questions in class. was nice after class however.
No Comments
He's not very interesting, and not very good at communicating concepts.
He seems very helpful at first but then if you approach him for help he seems to get an attitude and is a smart ass. He offers help sessions but is unapproachable so the help sessions are pointless.

oh what a class..his lectures were simple..like sometimes elementary.  So you think, wow I got this, but when the test rolls around its another story. The concepts were not that difficult, but I was not a fan of his teaching.
lectures are interesting.  his exams are somewhat unclear

weeks gives good notes and moves at a good pace, but when people ask him questions he makes them feel so stupid.  everyone is terrified to ask questions bc they dont want him to embariss them in front of the entire class.  i would recommend trying for a diff professor if you can

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: This class was a little unorganized, but luckily there are no tests. However, the problem sets given are difficult. Some things are taken directly from lecture notes, but others are application and hard to figure out. She is a great lecturer and excited about organic chemistry, but the overall class structure could have been changed.
She's extremely willing to explain things more when you don't understand them and cares a lot about her students outside of class. Best chemistry professor I've had so far.
Great lecturer, but definitely grades harder than most of the other orgo professors. Read the book! Tests are pretty difficult, but straightforward. Try not to fall behind in reading...
A great professor and her review sessions were very helpful.  Organic is a tough class and there's no getting around that, but she is one of the best professors that you can find for the class.

With Marcey, definitely go to class. She posts some, BUT NOT ALL, of her lecture notes online. This was a little killer when I studied for the tests after not paying enough attention in class. She is also big on doing practice problems in organic, so I'd recommend doing those to get a good grade. Otherwise, she's a pretty good lecturer.

Dr. Waters gives clear lectures and tests very fairly.  Do the practice problems, read the book, go to class.  Do not hesitate to go to her office hours if there is something that is unclear -- she is quite approachable.

Marcey Waters is an incredibly patient, helpful, and gifted professor. She's the best chem teacher I've ever had at UNC and she will ALWAYS explain things when you don't understand. It's no wonder she's won awards - she is a great professor. 5 stars.
great teacher and man is she so fine or what.  extremely attractive.  HIGHLY recommend.
She is so great
Boring material but overall not to hard of a class
Awesome professor.  Always available for help.  Makes otherwise boring information somewhat enjoyable. Definetly take this class at least the professor's easy on the eyes.
Explains things very well. Boring stuff but at least shes easy to look at.
explains info well...you will do well on tests if you do the recommended problems...webassign is a pain...but other than that the class is great!
She's pretty awesome, and pretty hot for a Chemistry teacher.

I loved this class!  Organic chemistry may seem hard at first, but its well worth the effort.  The teacher was always willing to help her students and often held review sessions, which I found very helpful.  The tests were hard, but fair. Lectures were also very helpful for understanding the material!
Marcey, stop padding the ratings by evaluating yourself.
Marcy is great and very understanding. The class is boring, but hey, not her fault, its just the material.

Good professor but really complex, boring material. Hard tests with very little curve. Would be a lot better if chem 61 involved anything more than memorizing *dozens* of reactions. I've heard Ashby is infinitely easier.
poor sense of humor.

she was very clear and organized in teaching the information and it was extremely helpful to go to class. organic was still hard, but she  helped with understanding the concepts. best chem teacher i've had at carolina!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Lectures are very monotone and old-fashioned on the chalkboard. Exams are hard, but not impossible w/very steep curve. Help-sessions are very helpful and I highly advise to attend.  Dr. Johnson is one of the kindest professors at UNC and really cares about his students.  He should win a Nobel Prize in Chemistry! (Take him and you'll get the joke)

He was usually pretty clear in lecture and would answer any questions that arose.  He knows his stuff...that being said, you should too.  The tests weren't impossible if you studied well...but it's orgo, so it will be hard.  He held a lot of review sessions, which was nice.
Didn't find his style of lecturing very helpful. Basically consisted of a lot of examples without much explanation as to why those examples worked the way they did.

He is really friendly and very helpful. He will answer questions in a 200+ lecture class to make sure everyone understands. He always has review sessions and is very approachable. That being said, orgo is a hard class and he definitely challenges you.

overall good prof. he may not be super funny or anything but he's friendly and helpful. he really tries to challenge you and can make questions seriously hard. he knows his stuff and I'd say he's pretty good at explaining. my only complaint is that sometimes it was boring, but I guess that's just how it has to be..

orgo is hard no matter what you do. he's very nice and respectful with questions and clear when he teaches..but expect to have to put everything together on your own...I've had all A's in my classes (i'm a junior) and I barely got a C in this course...prepare to study!!
Check out his hair!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Bloom loves his subject and this comes across in the lectures.  He does tend to get on tangents but is overall a great professor.  I always enjoyed his lectures, although they do switch professors half way through the semester for this class which was kind of annoying.

VERY passionate about his subject, and he knows his stuff. I'm not going to lie, he does go on tangents and it's a little fuzzy until he gets to his main point. However, he's very knowledgeable and makes an 8 am genetics class worth it. He's bad about answering emails though... and his second exam was a lot tougher than the first. Very nice man!
Hard class. Make sure you get the assigned readings done and pay attention to details he not only makes his exams from lecture but a lot of it comes from the readings. Hard exams.

He was obviously very knowledgeable but not able to communicate ideas to the class.  He jumped from subject to subject during lecture so it was hard to follow and take notes.  His tests were hard, but if you paid attention in class, read the textbook, and reviewed masteringgenetics, they were fair.

He liked what he taught but was very disorganized. He's one of those professors that's definitely a great researcher, but NOT a good at teaching. He assumes that you know about a LOT of things beforehand. The exams were extremely ambiguous and hard, especially the 1st one. Also, he never showed up to class on the days we had exams. NEVER.

He is a nice guy and means well and is very passionate about what he teaches. That being said he is very tangential in his lectures and kind of disorganized, so it ends up being quite confusing. Exams are crazy hard, i know many classmates that thought they had a firm grasp on the material that ended up nearly failing the tests.

He introduces an idea, goes to something else, then comes back to finish his point; the end result is sometimes confusing. Not very personable and his test questions are left fielders (even for me and I had a solid A), be ready for curve balls! But, he knows his stuff big time. Minus a couple of nasty test questions, exams are actually very fair.

Dr. Bloom is disorganized, does not explain concepts well, bounces to another concept without thoroughly explaining the first one.  He writes confusing tests and does not clearly express how he would like the questions to be answered.  Biology is a culture and he doesn't do a very good job in helping students integrate into that culture. Avoid him!

Bloom is not a good teacher. He rambles, and refuses to use any kind of technology to teach except Lego blocks (yeah, you read correctly!) and an overhead projector--he seems quite proud of this, too. Tests are somewhat hard, especially the first one. Do yourself a favor and take the other section of this clas.

I enjoyed Dr. Bloom's lectures much better than Dr. Dangl's.  Bloom went slowly through the more complicated material, which was very helpful.  I wouldn't recommend taking this class because as a pair, Bloom and Dangl make this class very difficult to understand

I'm a double science major and Bloom's class was by far my easiest science class at UNC.  He teaches the complicated parts patiently and the practice tests he gives are very helpful.  Do the practice tests and go to review sessions and this class is no problem.
The material isn't easy, but he's very approchable for questions after class.
I did not think either Kerry Bloom or Jeff Dangl were effective teachers. This class contains difficult material and I would advise taking it with someone else.

Somewhat scatterbrained, but generally a good teacher. Stops frequently for questions and goes slowly through difficult material, very much unlike his colleague (and co-professor) Jeff Dangl. Average-difficulty or difficult tests. Likes what he does, so learning from him is a bit easier.
